title: Ashes hero Steve Smith speaks out on becoming Australia captain again
text:
Steve Smith and current Australia Test captain Tim Paine (Picture: Getty)

Steve Smith has played down the possibility of becoming Australia captain again after his remarkable Ashes campaign.

Smith scored a staggering 774 runs in seven innings during last summer’s Ashes, helping Australia draw the series 2-2 and retain the urn.

Tim Paine captained Australia during that series, having taken over from Smith last year following his ban for ball-tampering.

Smith’s return to Australia’s Test team has sparked speculation he will soon be handed the captaincy again but the 30-year-old says ‘we will cross that bridge later’.

Paine’s Australia retained the Ashes in England last summer (Picture: Getty)

‘I’m not even thinking about that at the moment,’ Smith, who scored three centuries during the 2019 Ashes, said.

‘I was pretty chilled out the whole time in England. I’m obviously pretty intense when I am out there batting but I help out wherever I can.

‘I don’t want to sit back and not say something if I think it might help us.

‘We will cross that bridge later if it comes. At the moment I am comfortable and Tim is doing a great job.’

Smith failed in his first innings since the Ashes (Picture: Getty)

Smith has also revealed the gruelling summer – he also played a significant part in Australia’s run to the World Cup semi-finals – left him feeling cooked and fatigued.

He added: ‘It was probably a bit of everything: mental, emotional, physical.

‘Towards the last Test match it got to day two and my mind was saying keep going but my body had shut down and wouldn’t let me do anything.

Turns out Steve Smith is human after all! Out for a duck on a day of #SheffieldShield carnage at the Gabba pic.twitter.com/9LI8VPga8x — cricket.com.au (@cricketcomau) October 10, 2019

‘I was a little bit sick after that. I’ve had a good couple of weeks just to lay low. I just got back into things over the past week.’

In his first innings since the Ashes, Smith was dismissed for a five-ball duck as New South Wales slipped to 50-3 in reply to Queensland’s 153.

Australia opener David Warner, who endured a shocking run of form last summer, will resume on day two unbeaten on 27.
